title: 109_hr3098
content: The "Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act of 2005" is the short title of this Act. It addresses premiums for mortgage insurance. The "Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act of 2005" amends the Internal Revenue Code to treat premiums for qualified mortgage insurance as qualified residence interest for tax purposes. The deduction allowable for these premiums is reduced by 10 percent. The "Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act of 2005" allows for the deduction of qualified mortgage insurance premiums as qualified residence interest for tax purposes. The deduction is reduced by 10 percent for each $1,000 (or fraction thereof) that the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeds $100,000. The Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act of 2005 allows for the deduction of qualified mortgage insurance premiums as qualified residence interest for tax purposes, including mortgage insurance provided by government agencies and private mortgage insurance. Special rules apply for prepaid qualified mortgage insurance payments. The Mortgage Insurance Fairness Act of 2005 allows for the deduction of qualified mortgage insurance premiums as qualified residence interest for tax purposes. Payments made for such insurance can be allocated to specific periods and charged to capital account. No deduction is allowed for the unamortized balance if the mortgage is paid off early. This rule does not apply to payments for qualified mortgage insurance provided by certain government agencies. SEC. 3. INFORMATION RETURNS RELATING TO MORTGAGE INSURANCE. Section 6050H of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection requiring individuals receiving $600 or more in mortgage insurance premiums to make a return to the Secretary. This return must contain prescribed information and be furnished to each individual. Individuals receiving $600 or more in mortgage insurance premiums must make a return to the Secretary and provide a written statement to each individual by January 31 of the following year. The term 'mortgage insurance' includes insurance from various government agencies and private mortgage insurance. Private mortgage insurance, as defined by the Homeowners Protection Act of 1998, must be reported for individuals receiving $600 or more in premiums. The amendments made by this Act regarding private mortgage insurance reporting shall apply to amounts paid or accrued after the date of enactment in taxable years ending after such date.
